articles.headline: Brazilians Shrug Off Zika Fears to Revel in Carnival Fun
articles.snippet: Many Brazilians feel they have more important things to worry about, including soaring unemployment, a plummeting currency and a corruption scandal.
articles.abstract: Many Brazilians feel they have more important things to worry about, including soaring unemployment, a plummeting currency and a corruption scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALVADOR, Brazil — From a mosquito’s point of view, the sweaty, minimally clothed multitudes thronging the streets of this northeastern city on Monday night must have looked especially delectable.

articles.headline: The Real Jobless Rate Is 42 Percent? Donald Trump Has a Point, Sort Of
articles.snippet: That number works, but only if you count retirees, college students and stay-at-home parents.
articles.abstract: That number works, but only if you count retirees, college students and stay-at-home parents.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald Trump seems quite certain that the real unemployment rate is higher than the 4.9 percent that the Bureau of Labor Statistics has reported it to be. A lot higher.

articles.headline: A Multifront Republican Battle in South Carolina
articles.snippet: Heading to the state’s primaries, the G.O.P. candidates chasing Donald J. Trump are trying to show strength.
articles.abstract: Heading to the state’s primaries, the G.O.P. candidates chasing Donald J. Trump are trying to show strength.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C. — Donald J. Trump’s rivals for the Republican presidential nomination dug in Wednesday for a hard fight in the South Carolina primary, where Mr. Trump will seek to gain a clear upper hand in the 2016 race after his smashing victory in New Hampshire.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Department of Justice Sues Ferguson, Which Reversed Course on Agreement
articles.snippet: City leaders rejected a deal to overhaul the police force, setting up a court fight over excessive policing in a city that came to symbolize it.
articles.abstract: City leaders rejected a deal to overhaul the police force, setting up a court fight over excessive policing in a city that came to symbolize it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Department of Justice filed a civil rights lawsuit against Ferguson, Mo., on Wednesday, less than a day after the city rejected an agreement to overhaul its beleaguered criminal justice system and address allegations of widespread abuses by its police department.

articles.headline: Twitter User Growth Stalls, and the Chief Pledges to Make Fixes
articles.snippet: The problem, Twitter said, is that the service is still not always intuitive to use, and it comes with quirks that newcomers find difficult to grasp.
articles.abstract: The problem, Twitter said, is that the service is still not always intuitive to use, and it comes with quirks that newcomers find difficult to grasp.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jack Dorsey returned last year as chief executive of Twitter, the social media company he co-founded, he had a mandate: Right a sinking ship.

articles.headline: Stakes in Nevada Rise for Hillary Clinton as Caucuses Near
articles.snippet: After his defeat of Mrs. Clinton on Tuesday, Bernie Sanders will have a chance to prove himself in a state as racially diverse as Iowa and New Hampshire are not.
articles.abstract: After his defeat of Mrs. Clinton on Tuesday, Bernie Sanders will have a chance to prove himself in a state as racially diverse as Iowa and New Hampshire are not.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The Democratic presidential caucuses in Nevada were supposed to be an afterthought: lost in the shadows of high-profile battles in Iowa and New Hampshire, and fought in a state far off in the West where voters have a long, warm history with Bill and Hillary Clinton.

articles.headline: SolarCity and Other Rooftop Providers Face a Cloudier Future
articles.snippet: Losses at rooftop solar companies have mounted as some states have withdrawn their support, and cheap natural gas isn’t helping matters.
articles.abstract: Losses at rooftop solar companies have mounted as some states have withdrawn their support, and cheap natural gas isn’t helping matters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just two years ago, SolarCity and other rooftop solar providers were Wall Street darlings, and prospects for growth were flying high, as enthusiasm for solar power was seemingly boundless.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Twitter, to Save Itself, Must Scale Back World-Swallowing Ambitions
articles.snippet: A more prosperous and promising future for Twitter may be as a private company or as a smaller division of a tech or media giant.
articles.abstract: A more prosperous and promising future for Twitter may be as a private company or as a smaller division of a tech or media giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twitter is the world’s most important social network.

articles.headline: Russian Intervention in Syrian War Has Sharply Reduced U.S. Options
articles.snippet: Russian military action has changed the shape of a conflict that had effectively been stalemated for years, and suddenly, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and his allies have momentum.
articles.abstract: Russian military action has changed the shape of a conflict that had effectively been stalemated for years, and suddenly, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and his allies have momentum.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNICH — For months now the United States has insisted there can be no military solution to the Syrian civil war, only a political accord between President Bashar al-Assad and the fractured, divided opposition groups that have been trying to topple him.

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Intrigues South Carolina Town That Loves Hillary Clinton
articles.snippet: In Orangeburg, some voters who said in January that they would undoubtedly vote for Mrs. Clinton are now taking a closer look at her opponent.
articles.abstract: In Orangeburg, some voters who said in January that they would undoubtedly vote for Mrs. Clinton are now taking a closer look at her opponent.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORANGEBURG, S.C. — When Helen Duley was asked whom she would vote for in the South Carolina primary, she answered as if the very question were absurd.

articles.headline: Delivery Start-Ups Face Road Bumps in Quest to Capture Untapped Market
articles.snippet: Entrepreneurs and investors are discovering how complicated it can be to create a profitable delivery service.
articles.abstract: Entrepreneurs and investors are discovering how complicated it can be to create a profitable delivery service.
articles.lead_paragraph: DoorDash, one of a multitude of start-ups with a mobile app that lets people order and get food sent to their doorsteps, relies on contract drivers like Brian Navarro to make the deliveries. The problem is that workers like Mr. Navarro don’t always stick around.

articles.headline: Alan Grayson’s Double Life: Congressman and Hedge Fund Manager
articles.snippet: Documents show how Mr. Grayson’s work as a hedge fund manager at times interfered with his other duties as a U.S. lawmaker.
articles.abstract: Documents show how Mr. Grayson’s work as a hedge fund manager at times interfered with his other duties as a U.S. lawmaker.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The hedge fund manager boasted that he had traveled to “every country” in the world, studying overseas stock markets as he fine-tuned an investment strategy to capitalize on global companies’ suffering because of economic or political turmoil.
